{{About|biblical and patristic terminology pertaining to the Greek ''pneuma akatharton'' and related phrases||Pneuma}} {{For|related beliefs and practices|Demonic possession|Exorcism}} [[File:Duc De Berry - Besessener.jpg|300px|thumb|[[Jesus]] drives out a demon or '''unclean spirit''', from the 15th-century ''[[Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry|Très Riches Heures]]'']]
In [[English Bible translations|English translations of the Bible]], '''unclean spirit''' is a common rendering<ref>For instance, in the [[King James Version]], [[Wycliffe's Bible]], [[Tyndale Bible]], [[New Revised Standard Version]], [[American Standard Version]], [[International Standard Version]], [[World English Bible]], [[New English Translation]]; "foule sprete" in the [[Coverdale Bible]].</ref> of [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] '''''pneuma akatharton''''' (πνεῦμα ἀκάθαρτον; plural ''pneumata akatharta'' (πνεύματα ἀκάθαρτα)), which in its single occurrence in the [[Septuagint]] translates Hebrew ''{{lang|he-Latn|[[Ruach|ruaḥ]] [[Tumah|tum'ah]]}}'' ({{lang|he|רוח טומאה}}).
The Greek term appears 21 times in the [[New Testament]] in the context of [[demonic possession]].<ref>The term appears 21 times counting both singular and plural. J. Reiling, "Unclean spirits," in ''Dictionary of Deities and Demons in the Bible'', henceforth abbreviated ''DDD'' (William B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1999), p. 882 [https://books.google.com/books?id=yCkRz5pfxz0C&pg=PA882 online.]</ref> It is also translated into English as '''spirit of impurity'''<ref>As in the [[New International Version]]. See Karen Hartnup, ''On the Beliefs of the Greeks: [[Leo Allatius|Leo Allatios]] and Popular Orthodoxy'' (Brill, 2004), p. 88, especially note 16 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xnqI8uSeekwC&pg=PA88 online.]</ref> or more loosely as "evil spirit." The [[Latin]] equivalent is '''''spiritus immundus'''''.<ref>Pierre Maréchaux, "Les noces de [[Panurge]] et de [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercure]]: [[Rabelais]] et la leçon de [[Martianus Capella]]," in ''Études Rabelaisiennes'' 33 (1998), p. 167 [https://books.google.com/books?id=3gUn9yM769UC&pg=PA167 online.]</ref>
The association of physical and spiritual cleanliness is, if not universal, widespread and continues into the 21st century: "To be virtuous is to be physically clean and free from the impurity that is [[sin]]," notes an article in ''[[Scientific American]]'' published 10 March 2009.<ref>Gary Sherman and Gerald Clore, "Clean and Virtuous: When Physical Purity Becomes Moral Purity," ''Scientific American'' 10 March 2009, accessed [http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?id=embodied-metaphor-moral online] 20 April 2009; also [[WebCite]] [https://www.webcitation.org/5gB7t0WDy archive].</ref> Some scholarship<ref>Clinton Wahlen presents an overview of this scholarship in ''Jesus and the Impurity of Spirits in the Synoptic Gospels'' (Mohr Siebeck, 2004). For a table of terms used for evil powers in the New Testament, see p. 177 [https://books.google.com/books?id=6hrBXnXakq4C&pg=PA177&dq=%22Designations+for+Evil+Powers+in+the+New+Testament+1%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> seeks to differentiate between "unclean spirit" and "evil spirit" (''[[Unclean spirit#Pneuma poneron|pneuma ponêron]]'') or "demon" (''[[Daemon (classical mythology)|daimonion]]'').<ref>''DDD'', p. 882. For ''[[Daemon (mythology)|daimon]], not considered a synonym, see [[Unclean spirit#The concept of pneuma|The concept of ''pneuma'']] following.</ref>
==The concept of ''pneuma''== In the [[Bible|Christian scriptures]], the word <!--the following link to a disambiguation page is deliberate, as the overview of the concept of pneuma is more relevant than any one of the individual articles --> ''[[pneuma]]'' (plural ''pneumata'') is used variously for the human [[soul]], [[angel]]ic or [[demon]]ic [[spirit]]s, and the [[Holy Spirit]], depending on context or with a [[grammatical modifier]].<ref>Wayne A. Grudem, ''The [[First Epistle of Peter]]: An Introduction and Commentary'' (William B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1988) pp. 208–209 [https://books.google.com/books?id=z1mNYlDIL4EC&pg=PA208&dq=%22pneuma+has+a+range+of+meanings%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0#v=onepage&q=%22pneuma%20has%20a%20range%20of%20meanings%22&f=false online]; Eric Sorensen, ''Possession and Exorcism in the New Testament and Early Christianity'' (Mohr Siebeck, 2002), p. 121 [https://books.google.com/books?id=zh4o4LijeQkC&pg=PA121&dq=%22in+need+of+a+qualifying+word+or+context%22+intitle:Possession&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0#v=onepage&q=%22in%20need%20of%20a%20qualifying%20word%20or%20context%22%20intitle%3APossession&f=false online.]</ref> [[New Testament]] usage of the words ''pneuma'' and ''daimonion'' in relation to demons follows that of later [[Judaism]]; the two words are to be distinguished from ''[[daimon]]'', which appears only once (at {{bibleverse||Matthew|8:31}})<ref>''A Dictionary of Biblical Tradition in English Literature'', edited by David Lyle Jeffrey (William B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1992), p. 195; ''DDD'', p. 239.</ref> and in [[classical antiquity]] has a neutral meaning of "spirit" or "[[deity|god]], [[demigod]]."<ref>''Theological Dictionary of the New Testament'', edited by Gerhard Kittel and Gerhard Friedrich, translated and abridged by Geoffrey W. Bromley (William B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1985), p. 139 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ltZBUW_F9ogC&pg=PA139&dq=pneuma+akatharton&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA139,M1 online]; Dan Burton and David Grandy ''Magic, Mystery, and Science: The Occult in Western Civilization'' (Indiana University Press, 2003), p. 123 [https://books.google.com/books?id=vSWSSBU7EdwC&pg=PA123&dq=%22Although+the+Hebrew+Bible+makes+little+mention+of+Satan+and+demons%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> For those who practiced the traditional religions of antiquity, possession by a ''pneuma'' could be a desired state of [[Vision (spirituality)|visionary]] [[trance]].<ref>[[Greek Magical Papyri]] IV.1121–24, discussed under ''[[Unclean spirit#Pneuma pythona|Pneuma pythona]]'' below. See also David Edward Aune, ''Prophecy in Early Christianity and the Ancient Mediterranean World'' (William B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1983), p. 47 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Rwn7ofAwNQ4C&pg=PA268&dq=pneuma+%22unclean+spirit%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=1929&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA47,M1 online.]</ref>
In the New Testament, the Greek modifier ''akatharton'', although sometimes translated in context as "evil,"<ref>At Mark 1:23, for instance, the [[New Living Translation]] has "evil spirit," but glosses "Greek 'unclean'."</ref> means more precisely "impure, not purified," and reflects a concern for [[ritual purification]] shared with or derived from Judaism, though reinterpreted.<ref>''DDD'', p. 882, with additional citations. See also [[Ritual washing in Judaism]], [[Tumah]], and [[Mikvah]]. Connections and differences between Judaic impurity and Christian are explored extensively by Wahlen, ''Jesus and the Impurity of Spirits'', introduction, pp. 1–22.</ref> In [[early Christianity]], the [[catechumen]] was routinely prepared for [[baptism]] by [[exorcism]] even when demonic possession was not suspected; in the case of adult [[Religious conversion|converts]], the "unclean spirits" to be driven away might be identified with the gods of other religions.<ref>Indicated, for instance, by [[Tertullian]], ''Apologeticus'' 23.15-16. See Peter Cramer, ''Baptism and Change in the Early Middle Ages, c. 200–c. 1150'' (Cambridge University Press, 2003), ''passim'', especially the process as described by [[Hippolytus of Rome]], pp. 11ff [https://books.google.com/books?id=AueTHQdX9ngC&pg=PA10&dq=%22Much+of+what+Hippolytus+describes+is+a+movement+towards+crisis%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; Jeffrey Burton Russell, ''Satan: The Early Christian Tradition'' (Cornell University Press, 1987), p. 101 [https://books.google.com/books?id=MBWf4UVLex0C&pg=PA101&dq=%22Until+about+A.D.+200,+baptism+was+often+preceded+by+a+rite+of+exorcism%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; G.J. Riley, "Demon," in ''DDD'', pp. 235–240, especially p. 238 [https://books.google.com/books?id=yCkRz5pfxz0C&pg=PA238&dq=%22As+the+gods+of+the+nations+were+demonized%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] See also [[Unclean spirit#Pneuma pythona|Pneuma pythona]] below.</ref>
The practice of [[insufflation|insufflation and exsufflation]], or the use of released [[breath]] in ritual, depends on conceptualizing a spiritual entity as air in motion, "invisible yet active":<ref>''DDD'', p. 882.</ref> both Greek ''pneuma'' and Latin ''spiritus'' had an original meaning of "breath, mobile air."
== In Judaism == {{see also|Demon#Hebrew Bible|Jewish demonology}} [[File:Villacasale03.jpg|left|thumb|The Hebrew ''se’irim'', or "hairy demon," is sometimes translated "[[satyr]]," as depicted here in a [[mosaic|Roman mosaic]].]] References to a "spirit of impurity" or an "evil spirit" (''ruaḥ tum'ah'') are found in the Hebrew Bible, in [[Rabbinic literature]], and in [[Pseudepigrapha#Biblical Pseudepigrapha|Pseudepigrapha]].<ref>Howard Jacobson, ''A Commentary on [[Pseudo-Philo]]'s Liber Antiquitatum Biblicarum, with Latin Text and English Translation'' (Brill, 1996), vol. 2, p. 1118 [https://books.google.com/books?id=JtZ8T_zd_70C&pg=PA1118&dq=%22The+notions+of+%22spirit+of+impurity%22%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online] (equivalent [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]) phrases provided); postbiblical sources cited by Barry D. Smith, "Spirit, Evil/Unclean," in ''Eerdmans Dictionary of the Bible'', p. 1248 [https://books.google.com/books?id=P9sYIRXZZ2MC&pg=PA1248&dq=%22Postbiblical+Jewish+texts%22+intitle:Eerdmans+intitle:dictionary+intitle:of+intitle:the+intitle:Bible&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA1249,M1 online.]</ref> It can be difficult to distinguish between a demon and an unclean or evil spirit in Judaic theology or contemporary scholarship; both entities like to inhabit wild or desolate places. Commonly the '''unclean spirit''' refers to [[Dybbuk]]s, spirits of deceased persons who were not laid to rest and thus became [[demon]]s.<ref>http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/dibbuk-dybbuk</ref> Other demonic entities are ''[[shedim]]'', which appears only twice in the [[Tanakh]]; originally a [[loan-word]] from [[Akkadian language|Akkadian]] for a protective, benevolent spirit (''[[shedu|sedu]]''), but from Jewish perspective were [[false gods|foreign gods]] and according to established Jewish lore own beings, created by [[Jahwe]].<ref>''Shedim'' at {{bibleverse||Psalm|106:37}} and {{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|32:17}}. See W. Gunther Plaut, ''The [[Torah]]: A Modern Commentary'' (Union for Reform Judaism, 2005), p. 1403 [https://books.google.com/books?id=wCTfI2rpvXEC&pg=PP1422&dq=shedim&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; Dan Burton and David Grandy, ''Magic, Mystery, and Science: The Occult in Western Civilization'' (Indiana University Press, 2003), p. 120 [https://books.google.com/books?id=vSWSSBU7EdwC&pg=PA120&dq=%22The+Hebrew+term+for+demons%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref>
The ''[[se’irim]]'' or ''śa‘ir'' are goat-demons or "hairy demons"<ref>''Pilosi'', "the hairy ones," in the Church Fathers; Katherine Nell MacFarlane, "Isidore of Seville on the Pagan Gods (''Origines'' VIII. 11)," ''Transactions of the American Philosophical Society'' 70 (1980), pp. 35–36.</ref> (sometimes translated as "[[satyr]]s") associated with other harmful supernatural beings and with ruins, i.e., human structures that threaten to revert to the wild.<ref>''Se’irim'' in {{bibleverse||Leviticus|17:7}} and {{bibleverse|2|Chronicles|11:15}}. See Dan Ben-Amos, ''Folktales of the Jews: Tales from Eastern Europe'' (Jewish Publication Society, 2007), vol. 2, p. 37 [https://books.google.com/books?id=lE2mDIMk5mAC&pg=PA37&dq=%22The+second+term+se+%27irim%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online], and "On Demons," in ''Creation and Re-creation in Jewish Thought: [[Festschrift]] in Honor of Joseph Dan on the Occasion of His Seventieth Birthday'' (Mohr Siebeck, 2005), p. 29ff. [https://books.google.com/books?id=7Fg2TiVGRQ0C&pg=PA28&dq=%22The+legends+and+nomenclature+of+the+demonic+world+in+Jewish+tradition%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] Also ''A Dictionary of Biblical Tradition in English Literature'', pp. 194–195.</ref> The demonic figure [[Azazel]], depicted with goat-like features and in one instance as an [[Azazel#Personification of impurity|unclean bird]], is consigned to desert places as impure.<ref>Walter J. Houston, "Leviticus," in ''Eerdmans Commentary on the Bible'' (Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 2003), p. 114 [https://books.google.com/books?id=2Vo-11umIZQC&pg=PA114&dq=unclean+Azazel+OR+Azaziel&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3#v=onepage&q=unclean%20Azazel%20OR%20Azaziel&f=false online]; Daniel C. Harlow, ''The Greek Apocalypse of Baruch (3 Baruch) in Hellenistic Judaism and Early Christianity'' (Brill, 1996), p. 66 [https://books.google.com/books?id=2KY-CEsMdOIC&pg=PA66&dq=unclean+Azazel+OR+Azaziel&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3#v=onepage&q=unclean%20Azazel%20OR%20Azaziel&f=false online]; Bernard Jacob Bamberger, ''Fallen Angels: Soldiers of Satan's Realm'' (Jewish Publication Society, 1952, repub. 2006), p. 46 [https://books.google.com/books?id=55cg5iLlCZYC&pg=PA46&dq=unclean+Azazel+OR+Azaziel&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3#v=onepage&q=unclean%20Azazel%20OR%20Azaziel&f=false online.]</ref> The [[Babylonian Talmud]]<ref>[[Sanhedrin]] 65b.</ref> says that a person who wanted to attract an impure spirit might fast and spend the night in a [[cemetery]];<ref>Jonathan Seidel, "Magical Texts of the Cairo [[Geniza]]," in ''Spirit Possession in Judaism'' (Wayne State University Press, 2003), p. 88, note 14.</ref> in the traditional religions of the [[Near East]] and [[Europe]], one ritual mode for seeking a divinely inspired [[revelation]] or [[prophecy]] required [[incubation (ritual)|incubation]] at the [[tomb]] of an ancestor or [[Greek hero cult|hero]].<ref>Daniel Ogden, ''Greek and Roman [[Necromancy]]'' (Princeton University Press, 2001), ''passim'', part 1, chapters 1–6.</ref> A cemetery, already a [[wikt:locus|locus]] of "unclean" spirits or a multiplicity of gods, was considered an appropriate [[landfill|dump]] when biblical leaders destroy sacred objects of other religions or statues representing the gods.<ref>{{bibleverse|2|Kings|23:6}} and {{bibleverse|2|Chronicles|34:4}}, the latter specifying the [[Kidron Valley]], where there were many tombs; see Joe M. Sprinkle, "Grave," in ''Eerdmans Dictionary of the Bible'', p. 527.</ref> ''To pneuma to akatharton'' appears in the Septuagint at {{bibleverse||Zechariah|13:2}},<ref>A Greek text with French translation may be viewed [http://ba.21.free.fr/septuaginta/zacharie/zacharie_13.html online.]</ref> where ''pseudoprophetai'' ("[[false prophet]]s") speak in the name of [[YHWH|Yahweh]] but are possessed by an unclean spirit.<ref>Cristiano Grottanelli, "Possessed [[Transsexuals]] in Antiquity: A Double Transformation," in ''Self and Self-Transformation in the History of Religions'' (Oxford University Press, 2002), p. 101 [https://books.google.com/books?id=_KTlN6scwQcC&pg=PA101&dq=pneuma+akatharton&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA101,M1 online.]</ref> This occurrence of "unclean spirit" is unique in the Tanakh; the Hebrew is ''rûah hattum’â''.<ref>''DDD'', p. 882.</ref>
The [[Magic in the Greco-Roman world|syncretic magical practice]] of [[late antiquity]] drew on Hebraic elements, and spells from the Greek Magical Papyri evoke and attempt to command Jewish angels, demons, and other beings regarded as spiritually powerful. At one point, a compiler of the magical text emphasizes the Jewish aspect of purity, insisting that "this spell is Hebraic and is preserved among pure men", advising that the practitioner should keep himself pure and [[Kashrut|refrain from eating pork]].<ref>[[Pieter Willem van der Horst]], "The Great Magical Papyrus of Paris (PGM IV) and the Bible," in ''Jews and Christians in Their Graeco-Roman Context'' (Mohr Siebeck, 2006), pp. 269–279, especially p. 277, limited preview [https://books.google.com/books?id=-AfzCmGh3fsC&printsec=frontcover&dq=intitle:Jews+intitle:and+intitle:Christians+intitle:in+intitle:Their+intitle:Graeco-Roman+intitle:Context&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA269,M1 online.] An English translation of the complete exorcism may be viewed in Daniel Odgen, ''Magic, Witchcraft, and Ghosts in the Greek and Roman Worlds: A Sourcebook'' (Oxford University Press US, 2002), pp. 169–170 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ox3QRxWQQtcC&pg=PA169&dq=%22A+Judaeo-Christian-influenced+exorcism+spell%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] It has been pointed out that since refraining from pork is a special preparation for the spell, the seeker of its effects was likely not Jewish, but a gentile who wanted the efficacy of Jewish magic; see Lynn LiDonnici, "According to the Jews: Identified (and Identifying) 'Jewish' Elements in the ''Greek Magical Papyri''," ''Heavenly Tablets: Interpretation, Identity and Tradition in Ancient Judaism'' (Brill, 2007), pp. 98–99.</ref> The spell concludes with a protracted [[insufflation]]. A tradition of [[Solomon#Demons and magic|Solomonic]] exorcism continued into medieval Europe; an example is recorded by [[Gregory Thaumaturgus|Gregory the Thaumaturge]]: "I adjure you all unclean spirits by [[Elohim]], [[Adonai]], [[Sabaoth]], to come out and depart from the [[servant of God]]."<ref>[[Gregory Thaumaturgus|Gregory the Thaumaturge]], ''Precatio et exorcismus'' ([[Patrologia Graeca]] 36.734), cited by Jonathan Seidel, "Magical Texts of the Cairo Geniza," in ''Spirit Possession in Judaism'', p. 92, note 39 [https://books.google.com/books?id=CF1C84xHeucC&pg=PA253&dq=%22demonic+possession%22+Judaism+OR+jewish&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA92,M1 online.] Full discussion by David R. Jordan and Roy D. Kotansky, "A Solomonic Exorcism," in ''Kölner Papyri (P. Köln)'', vol. 8 (Abhandlungen der Nordrhein-Westfälischen Akademie der Wissenschaften. Sonderreihe, Papyrologia Coloniensia), Sonderreihe vol. VII/8 (Opladen: Westdeutscher, 1997), no. 338, pp. 53–69.</ref>
Exorcism is the most thoroughly attested [[Magic in the Greco-Roman world#Jewish magic|Jewish magical practice]] of the [[Second Temple]] period. The exorcistic technique of [[Incense|fumigation by incense]] depends on the aerial conception of the unclean spirit: the occupation of air by [[odor]] or [[smoke]] (i.e., airborne particulate matter) was supposed to drive off or displace an unclean spirit.<ref>Gideon Bohak, ''Ancient Jewish Magic: A History'' (Cambridge University Press, 2008) p. 88 [https://books.google.com/books?id=DpJlOHceIjMC&pg=PA88&dq=%22Of+all+the+Jewish+magical+practices+of+the+SEcond+Temple+period,+exorcism%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; for an extensive discussion of Jewish exorcism, see pp. 88–118 (limited preview). On Jewish exorcism in relation to the [[New Testament]], see Eric Eve, ''The Jewish Context of Jesus' Miracles'' (Continuum International Publishing Group, 2002) pp. 326–333, limited preview [https://books.google.com/books?id=UGiOuJjDZTkC&pg=PA326&dq=%22Jewish+exorcists%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> Since either body or soul could be unclean, it can be difficult to distinguish exorcism from traditional magico-medical practice in which a [[personification|personified]] illness is adjured to depart from the patient's body (for instance, "Flee, Fever!") by means of a charm, spoken or [[epigraphy|inscribed]] on an [[amulet]] or other ritual object.<ref>Roy Kotansky, “Incantations and Prayers on Inscribed Greek Amulets,” in ''Magika Hiera: Ancient Greek Magic and Religion'', edited by Christopher A. Faraone and Dirk Obbink (Oxford University Press, 1991), pp. 113–114 and 119. For an example from the [[Solomon#Demons and magic|Solomonic]] tradition, see [[Medicina Plinii#Sample remedies|Medicina Plinii: Sample remedies]].</ref> In some rabbinic literature, demons are viewed as inflicting evil on humans in part through illness and disease, though [[Mishnah]] and [[Tannaim|Tannaitic]] scholars in [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] did not view demons as the cause of illness.<ref>Distinctions discussed in ''The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia'' (William B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1995), vol. 1, pp. 921–922 [https://books.google.com/books?id=wo8csizDv0gC&pg=PA922&dq=exorcism+healing+unclean+illness&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA922,M1 online.]</ref>
==In Christianity== [[File:Judea 2 by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Judea]]n desert, a [[liminality|liminal]] space thought hospitable to '''unclean spirits''' ({{bibleverse||Matthew|12:43}})]] {{see also|Christian demonology|Miracles attributed to Jesus#Exorcisms}}
The exorcism of demons and unclean spirits is one of the major categories of [[miracles attributed to Jesus]]. In the [[Novum Testamentum Graece|Greek New Testament]], 20 occurrences of ''pneuma akatharton'' (singular and plural) are found in the [[Synoptic Gospels]], [[Acts of the Apostles]], and the [[Book of Revelation]].<ref>''DDD'', p. 882.</ref> The phrase may be used instead of ''daimonion'' (50 occurrences)<ref>''DDD'', p. 239.</ref> or a verbal form of ''daimonizesthai'', "to be possessed by a demon" or "to be or act as a demoniac,"<ref>Verbal form at Matthew 4:24; 8:16, 28, 33; 9:32; 12:22; 15:22; Mark 1:32; 5:15ff; ''A Dictionary of Biblical Tradition'', p. 195.</ref> as indicated by usage in parallel versions of the same story.<ref>Compare {{bibleverse||Mark|6:7}} and {{bibleverse||Matthew|10:1}}, where Jesus gives his disciples power to cast out "unclean spirits" (''pneuma akatharta'') with the parallel passage at {{bibleverse||Luke|9:1}}, where the word ''daimonia'' is used; also {{bibleverse||Mark|7:25}}, "unclean spirit," and {{bibleverse||Matthew|15:22}}, ''daimonizetai''; see ''DDD'', p. 882.</ref> Throughout [[The Gospel of Mark]], the terms ''pneuma'' (with a pejorative modifier) and ''daimonion'' seem to be equivalent.<ref>John R. Donahue and Daniel J. Harrington, ''The Gospel of Mark'' (The Liturgical Press, 2002), p. 80 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xZAIsUZOwSQC&pg=PA80&dq=pneuma+%22unclean+spirit%22+akatharton+OR+acatharton&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] For a table on Mark's demonological terminology, see Clinton Wahlen, ''Jesus and the Impurity of Spirits in the Synoptic Gospels'' (Mohr Siebeck, 2004), p. 120 [https://books.google.com/books?id=6hrBXnXakq4C&pg=PA120&dq=%22summary+of+demonological+terminology+in+Matthew%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] Throughout his book, Wahlen seeks to refine scholarly perception of the term ''pneuma akatharton'' and to distinguish its usage in the synoptic gospels.</ref>
In the narratives pertaining to the [[ministry of Jesus]], [[temptation]] to [[sin]] is not the primary role played by demons, but rather the causing of disease, disability, mental illness, and antisocial behavior; they defile and compel their human hosts to suffer both physically and spiritually. Although healing and exorcism are distinguished,<ref>See {{bibleverse||Matthew|4:24}} and {{bibleverse||Mark|1:32}}.</ref> they often appear in close association, and some afflictions are caused by demonic possession: the inability to speak at {{bibleverse||Matthew|9:32}}, blindess at {{bibleverse||Matthew|12:22}}, deafness at {{bibleverse||Mark|9:17–29}}, [[epilepsy]] at {{bibleverse||Matthew|17:18}}, and fever and other diseases at {{bibleverse||Luke|4:39}} and {{bibleverse||Luke|8:2}}. [[Mental disorder|Mental illness]], however, was the most common result.<ref>''DDD'', pp. 237, 239.</ref>
The exorcism of an unclean spirit was the first act of Jesus's public ministry:<ref>Geoffrey W. Bromley, ''International Standard Bible Encyclopedia'' (William B. Eerdmans, 1994), p. 789</ref>
{{cquote|<sup>21</sup>They went to [[Capernaum]], and when the [[Biblical Sabbath|Sabbath]] came, Jesus went into the [[synagogue]] and began to teach. <sup>22</sup>The people were amazed at his teaching, because he taught them as one who had [[authority]], not as the teachers of [[Halakha|the law]]. <sup>23</sup>Just then a man in their synagogue who was possessed by an unclean spirit cried out, <sup>24</sup>"What do you want with us, Jesus of [[Nazareth#New Testament times and associations|Nazareth]]? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are — the Holy One of God!" <sup>25</sup>"Be quiet!" said Jesus sternly. "Come out of him!" <sup>26</sup>The unclean spirit shook the man violently and came out of him with a shriek. <sup>27</sup>The people were all so amazed that they asked each other, "What is this? A new teaching — and with authority! He even gives orders to unclean spirits and they obey him." <sup>28</sup>News about him spread quickly over the whole region of [[Galilee]].<ref>{{bibleverse||Mark|1:21–28}}. This is the translation of the [[New International Version]], with one exception: the NIV translates ''akatharton'' as "evil," with a note pointing out that the Greek means "unclean."</ref>}}
Although "clean" and "unclean" were categories that served as markers of identity for Jews, distinguishing them from other nations and expressing [[Land of Israel|Israel's]] special "[[vocation]] to [[sacred|holiness]]," Jesus dismissed Jewish purity [[Religious law|laws]] and in {{bibleverse||Mark|7:1–23}} told his disciples they could violate them. He touched those who were in ritual terms "unclean," including [[Leprosy#Rome|lepers]], and healed them.<ref>Timothy A. Lenghar, "Clean and Unclean," ''Eerdmans Dictionary of the Bible," pp. 262–263.</ref>
Jesus is said to have directly granted his [[12 Disciples|12 disciples]] the power to cast out unclean spirits and to heal.<ref>{{bibleverse||Mark|6:7}}, {{bibleverse||Matthew|10:1}}, {{bibleverse||Luke|9:1}}.</ref> At {{bibleverse||Luke|9:49–50}}, [[John the Apostle]] reports that he and his fellow disciples have asked a man to stop casting out demons in the name of Jesus "because he isn't one of us," but Jesus replies that the man should be allowed to continue, since "anyone who is not against you is for you."<ref>Translation from the [[Contemporary English Version]].</ref> Elsewhere, Jesus appoints 72<ref>Or 70 missionaries in some [[manuscript]]s.</ref> [[missionary|missionaries]] who also have the power to cast out demons.<ref>{{bibleverse||Luke|10:17–20}}; ''daimonia'' in the missionaries' terminology (10.17), ''pneumata'' in the words of Jesus (10.20). At {{bibleverse||Mark|16:17}}, the newly resurrected Christ says that the ability to drive out demons (''daimonia'') in his name is a sign of the [[belief|true believer]].</ref>
[[File:Haeckel Batrachia.jpg|left|thumb|Frogs of the [[amphibian]] class Batrachia ([[Ernst Haeckel|Haeckel]], 1904); [[Book of Revelation|Revelation]] compares three ''pneumata'' to [[frogs]] (Greek ''batrachoi''), an [[Kashrut|'''unclean''' animal]]]]
===Animals and liminality=== The attribution of animal-like qualities to demons continues from the Jewish tradition; like demons, [[Unclean animals|animals may be classified as "unclean."]] {{bibleverse||Revelation|16:13}} describes "three unclean spirits like [[Frogs in popular culture|frog]]s" (''pneumata tria akatharta hôs [[Batrachia|batrachoi]]''); frogs are unclean as animals for food in the [[Kashrut|Jewish dietary code]].<ref>This and more on frogs in the Bible from Victoria Andrews, "Frogs," in ''Eerdmans Dictionary of the Bible'' p. 472 [https://books.google.com/books?id=P9sYIRXZZ2MC&pg=PA472&dq=frogs+unclean+dietary+kashrut+OR+jewish&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; also "Clean and Unclean," pp. 262–262. It has sometimes been argued that frogs are clean; see discussion by Seth Daniel Kunin, ''We Think What We Eat: Neo-structuralist Analysis of [[Israelite]] Food Rules and Other Cultural and Textual Practices'' (Continuum International, 2004), pp. 47–48 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Rggvu8zvtGIC&pg=PA47&dq=frogs+unclean+dietary+kashrut+OR+jewish&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA47,M1 online.] See also articles on [[Frogs in popular culture]] and the [[Egyptian pantheon|Egyptian goddess]] [[Heqet]].</ref> The association of unclean spirits with [[liminality|liminal]] areas such as ruins, cemeteries, and [[desert]]s also continues from Judaic belief; {{bibleverse||Revelation|18:2}} speaks of the future ruin of [[Babylon (New Testament)|Babylon]] as "a dwelling place of every unclean spirit and a haunt of every unclean and hateful bird."
Both animalism and [[Liminality#In places|transitional, liminal sites]] (marked in '''bold''' following) are involved in perhaps the most famous manifestation of an unclean spirit in the New Testament, the [[Legion (demon)|Gerasene demon whose name is Legion]]:
[[File:Healing of the demon-possessed.jpg|left|thumb|Medieval illustration of Jesus casting out the '''unclean''' [[Legion (demon)|Gerasene demon]]]] {{cquote|<sup>1</sup>And they ''[Jesus and his followers]'' came to the other '''side of the sea''',<ref>For the connection of demons to the sea, see for instance [[Abyzou#Origins|Abyzou: Origins]].</ref> as into the [[Jerash|country of the Gerasenes]]. <sup>2</sup> And when he was come out of the boat, straightway there met him out of the '''tombs''' a man with an unclean spirit ''(pneumati akathartoi)'', <sup>3</sup>who had his dwelling in the tombs: and no man could any more bind him, no, not with a chain; <sup>4</sup>because that he had been often bound with fetters and chains, and the chains had been rent asunder by him, and the fetters broken in pieces: and no man had strength to tame him. <sup>5</sup>And always, night and day, '''in the tombs and in the mountains''', he was crying out, and cutting himself with stones. <sup>6</sup>And when he saw Jesus from afar, he ran and worshipped him; <sup>7</sup>and crying out with a loud voice, he saith, What have I to do with thee, Jesus, thou Son of the Most High God? I adjure thee by God, torment me not. <sup>8</sup>For he said unto him, Come forth, thou unclean spirit ''(pneuma akatharton)'', out of the man. <sup>9</sup>And he asked him, What is thy name? And he saith unto him, My name is Legion; for we are many. <sup>10</sup>And he besought him much that he would not send them away out of the country. <sup>11</sup>Now there was there on the '''mountain side''' a great herd of [[Pig|swine]] feeding. <sup>12</sup>And they besought him, saying, Send us into the swine, that we may enter into them. <sup>13</sup>And he gave them leave. And the unclean spirits ''(ta pneumata ta akatharta)'' came out, and entered into the swine: and the herd rushed '''down the steep bank into the sea''', in number about two thousand; and they were drowned in the sea. <sup>14</sup>And they that fed them fled, and told it in the city, and in the country. And they came to see what it was that had come to pass. <sup>15</sup>And they come to Jesus, and behold him that was possessed with demons sitting, clothed and in his right mind, even him that had the legion: and they were afraid. <sup>16</sup>And they that saw it declared unto them how it befell him that was possessed with demons, and concerning the swine. <sup>17</sup>And they began to beseech him to depart from their '''borders'''. <sup>18</sup>And as he was '''entering into the boat''', he that had been possessed with demons besought him that he might be with him. <sup>19</sup>And he suffered him not, but saith unto him, Go to thy house unto thy friends, and tell them how great things the Lord hath done for thee, and how he had mercy on thee. <sup>20</sup>And he went his way, and began to publish in [[Decapolis]] how great things Jesus had done for him: and all men marvelled.<ref>{{bibleverse||Mark|5:1–20}}, quoted here in the [[American Standard Version]].</ref>}}
The [[Pigs#Pigs in religion|pig]] is a suitable recipient because it is an unclean animal. "It was certainly not very kind to the pigs," the philosopher [[Bertrand Russell]] remarked, "to put the devils into them and make them rush down the hill to the sea."<ref>[[Bertrand Russell]], "[[Why I Am Not a Christian]]," republished in ''The Collected Papers of Bertrand Russell'' (Routledge, 1996), vol. 10, p. 190 [https://books.google.com/books?id=oEoi0HnF7j0C&pg=RA1-PA190&dq=%22instance+of+the+Gadarene+swine%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3 online.]</ref> The need for the demonic ''pneuma'' to transmigrate into another body is expressed also at {{bibleverse||Matthew|12:43}}, where desert is a haunt for the restless spirit:
{{cquote|When an unclean spirit comes out of a man, it goes through arid places seeking rest and does not find it.<ref>Translation from the [[New International Version]], except that ''akatharton pneuma'' is translated as "evil spirit" but glossed as "unclean."</ref>}}
===''Pneuma poneron''=== [[File:John Collier - Priestess of Delphi.jpg|thumb|''Priestess of Delphi'' (1891) by [[John Collier (Pre-Raphaelite painter)|John Collier]]; the [[Pythia]] was inspired by a '''''pneuma''''' rising from below]] The phrase ''pneuma poneron'' (πνεῦμα πονηρόν, "evil spirit") is used several times in the Septuagint, the New Testament<ref>{{bibleverse||Matthew|12:45}}; {{bibleverse||Luke|7:21}} {{bibleverse||Luke|8:2}}, and {{bibleverse||Luke|11:26}}; {{bibleverse||Acts|19:12–13}} and {{bibleverse||Acts|15–16}}.</ref> and also in [[Church Fathers|patristic texts]] as an alternative to ''pneuma akatharton''.<ref>Edward John Hamilton, ''Rational Orthodoxy'' (New York, 1917), p. 445.</ref>
The [[Divination|divinatory]] [[Trance#Origins and history|trance]] of the [[Pythia]] — the female [[Oracle of Delphi|oracle]] of [[Apollo]] at [[Delphi]] — is attributed by the 4th-century [[Church Fathers|patristic authority]] [[John Chrysostom]] to a ''pneuma poneron'':
{{cquote|The Pythia is seated on [[Sacrificial tripod|Apollo's tripod]], her legs spread. An evil spirit (''pneuma poneron'') rises from below, enters her [[vagina]], and fills her with madness. Her hair is disheveled, and foam flows from her mouth: she is like a [[Maenad|bacchante]]. And it is in such a state that she speaks.<ref>[[John Chrysostom]], ''[[Homily|Homilies]] on the [[Pauline epistles|Epistles of Paul]] to the [[Corinth#Roman era|Corinthians]]'', Homily 29 on [[First Epistle to the Corinthians|1 Corinthians]], as translated and cited in Giulia Sissa, ''Greek Virginity'' (Harvard University Press, 1990), p. 23. [[Origen]], ''[[Contra Celsum]]'' 3.25 (pre-dating Chrysostom), makes a similar remark; see under [[Unclean spirit#Pneuma pythona|Pneuma pythona below]].</ref>}}
Chrysostom uses the phrase ''pneuma poneron'' frequently in his writings; it is typically translated "evil spirit." The nature of the vapors that inspired the Pythia has been the subject of much debate; see [[Pythia#Science and the Pythia|Science and the Pythia]]. For the Greeks, the Pythia was characterized by [[sexual purity]]; her [[virginity]] is asserted in some sources, but in others she is said only to have dressed as a virgin and to have lived chastely, and was either an old woman or a married woman who gave up her family and [[Carnal knowledge|carnal relations]] to serve the god.<ref>Barbara E. Goff, ''Citizen Bacchae: Women's Ritual Practice in Ancient Greece'' (University of California Press, 2004), pp. 222–223 [https://books.google.com/books?id=y-2K_zG3w7QC&pg=RA2-PA222&dq=%22The+question+of+the+Pythia%27s+upbringing+is,+of+course,+allied+to+that+of+her+sexual+experience%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; Matthew Dillon, ''Girls and Women in Classical Greek Religion'' (Routledge, 2003), p. 77 [https://books.google.com/books?id=h8XRyWmwVtoC&pg=PA77&dq=%22The+Pythia+at+Delphi+could+be+married%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; Paul Ciholas, ''The [[Omphalos]] and the [[Christian cross|Cross]]: Pagans and Christians in Search of a Divine Center'' (Mercer University Press, 2003), pp. 80–83 [https://books.google.com/books?id=rkPa3-bo_70C&pg=PA80&dq=%22At+first+the+god+chose+as+his+Pythia+a+young+virgin%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; Mary F. Foskett, ''A Virgin Conceived: [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Mary]] and Classical Representations of Virginity'' (Indiana University Press, 2002), p. 38 [https://books.google.com/books?id=emU9rEq6XvkC&pg=PA38&dq=Pythia+virgin+OR+virginity+OR+maiden&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> A spell invoking Apollo in the Greek Magical Papyri requires [[ritual purification]] in the form of dietary restrictions and sexual [[abstinence]]; the spell implies that a [[sexual intercourse|sexual union]] with the god will result.<ref>PGM I.290–292, in [[Hans Dieter Betz]], ''The Greek Magical Papyri in Translation'', p. 10 [https://books.google.com/books?id=K0hCj5u3HNQC&pg=PA10&dq=%22Apollonian+50+invocation%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> The vapors said to arise from the grotto at Delphi were a ''pneuma enthousiastikon'', "inspiring exhalation," according to [[Plutarch]].<ref>Aune, ''Prophecy in Early Christianity'', p. 34. For more on Plutarch's views of the ''pneuma'', see p. 355, note 135 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Rwn7ofAwNQ4C&pg=PA268&dq=pneuma+%22unclean+spirit%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=1929&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA355,M1 online.]</ref> Although the vaginal reception of the ''pneuma'' may strike the 21st-century reader as strange, [[Incense|fumigation]] was a not uncommon [[Gynecology#History|gynecological]] regimen throughout the [[Hippocratic Corpus]] and was employed as early as 1900–1500 BC in [[ancient Egyptian medicine]].<ref>Vivian Nutton, ''Ancient Medicine'' (Routledge, 2004), p. 41 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Q6hADumNHeIC&pg=PA416&dq=%22John+Chrysostom%22+Pythia+OR+oracle+OR+Pythoness&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&hl=en#PPA41,M1 online]; Cristina Mazzoni, ''Saint Hysteria: Neurosis, Mysticism and Gender in European Culture'' (Cornell University Press, 1996), p. 7 [https://books.google.com/books?id=QX7QnEIcuZUC&pg=PA7&dq=fumigation+Hippocratic+OR+gynecology+OR+gynaecology&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] Overview of fumigation in ancient Greek gynecology in W.J. Steward McKay, ''The History of Ancient Gynaecology'' (London, 1901), pp. 270–271 [https://books.google.com/books?id=mjMJAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA270&dq=fumigation+Hippocratic+OR+gynecology+OR+gynaecology&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA270,M1 online.] Additional passages, including [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] examples, from Carol Falvo Heffernan, ''The [[Phoenix (mythology)|Phoenix]] at the Fountain: Images of Woman and [[Eternity]] in [[Lactantius]]'s Carmen de Ave Phoenice and the [[Old English]] [[Phoenix (Old English poem)|Phoenix]]'' (University of Delaware Press, 1988), pp. 84–86 [https://books.google.com/books?id=tty4IP_1uKoC&pg=PA84&dq=fumigation+Hippocratic+OR+gynecology+OR+gynaecology&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA86,M1 online.]</ref> Gynecological fumigation was also a technique of [[History of medicine#Hebrew medicine|traditional Jewish medicine]].<ref>Ron Barkai, ''A History of Jewish Gynaecological Texts in the Middle Ages'' (Brill, 1998), presents English translations of several texts with examples of fumigation. ''A Record of the Diseases in the Genital Members'': therapies for the [[uterus]], p. 132 [https://books.google.com/books?id=PXvPxoKluyYC&pg=PP9&dq=fumigation+Hippocratic+OR+gynecology+OR+gynaecology&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=0_1#PPA132,M1 online]; [[menstruation|menstrual]] difficulty, p. 139 [https://books.google.com/books?id=PXvPxoKluyYC&pg=PP9&dq=fumigation+Hippocratic+OR+gynecology+OR+gynaecology&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=0_1#PPA139,M1 online], pp. 141 and 143 [https://books.google.com/books?id=PXvPxoKluyYC&pg=PP9&dq=fumigation+Hippocratic+OR+gynecology+OR+gynaecology&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=0_1#PPA143,M1 online.] ''[[Galen]]'s Book on the Womb, Which Is Called Genicias'': distress of the uterus, requiring dual fumigation along with the nose, p. 162 [https://books.google.com/books?id=PXvPxoKluyYC&pg=PP9&dq=fumigation+Hippocratic+OR+gynecology+OR+gynaecology&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=0_1#PPA162,M1 online.] ''Liber de Sinthomatibus Mulierum'': for an unexpelled [[placenta]], p. 189 [https://books.google.com/books?id=PXvPxoKluyYC&pg=PA189&dq=fumigation+Hippocratic+OR+gynecology+OR+gynaecology&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] ''[[Medicament]] for [[Pregnancy]] Called the Head Shield'': [[tablet (pharmacy)|tablet]]s for use in fumigation and as [[suppository|suppositories]], pp. 201–202 [https://books.google.com/books?id=PXvPxoKluyYC&pg=PP9&dq=fumigation+Hippocratic+OR+gynecology+OR+gynaecology&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=0_1#PPA201,M1 online]; fumigation (through a tube) for [[childbirth|delivery]], involving [[Sulfosalt minerals|arsenic sulfur]], [[donkey]] dung, and [[Pitch (resin)|pitch]], p. 204 [https://books.google.com/books?id=PXvPxoKluyYC&pg=PP9&dq=fumigation+Hippocratic+OR+gynecology+OR+gynaecology&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=0_1#PPA204,M1 online.]</ref> The intertwining of the medical and divinatory arts in [[Apollo]]nian religion<ref>Expressed in rational medicine as [[prognosis]].</ref> was characterized as demonic by Christian writers.<ref>Adelina Angusheva, "Late Medieval Witch Mythologies in the Balkans," in ''Witchcraft Mythologies and Persecutions'' (Central European University Press, 2008), p. 91 [https://books.google.com/books?id=dy0Eympsh7MC&pg=PA91&dq=%22Similarly+to+Joseph%27s+sermons,+the+treatise+of+St.+Nikodimos+displays+a+wide+picture+of+magic+practices,+but+focuses+mainly+on+stigmatizing%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> As a form of ritual purification, fumigation was intended to enhance the Pythia's receptivity to divine communication; to the men of the Church, the open vagina that served no [[Human reproduction|reproductive]] purpose was an uncontrolled form of [[human sexuality|sexuality]] that invited demonic influence, necessarily rendering the Pythia's [[prophecy|prophecies]] false.<ref>Alain Boureau, ''The Myth of [[Pope Joan]]'', translated by Lydia G. Cochrane (University of Chicago Press, 2001; originally published 1988), p. 188 [https://books.google.com/books?id=UVw09a69vcMC&pg=PA188&dq=%22pneuma+poneron%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA188,M1 online]; Paul Ciholas, ''The Omphalos and the Cross'', chapter 3, "The Prophet and the Pythia," especially pp. 82–83 [https://books.google.com/books?id=rkPa3-bo_70C&pg=PA82&dq=%22Christian+writers+adduced%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] See also [[Sexuality in Christian demonology]].</ref>
====''Pneuma pythona''==== The phrase ''pneuma pythona'.' (or ''puthona'') means "Pythonian spirit" or "divinatory spirit," and occurs only once in the New Testament. In {{bibleverse||Acts|16:16–18}}, after [[Saint Paul|Paul]] and [[Silas]] visit a woman of [[Thyatira]], they are greeted on their way to [[synagogue]] by a "working girl" (''paidiskê''), a slave who has earned a reputation as a gifted diviner; she is said to have a ''pneuma pythona'', not ''akatharton'' or ''poneron'', though the spirit is presumed to be evil. Through her employment she earns significant income for her masters. The adjective ''pythona'' indicates a connection to the cult of Apollo, regarded as the greatest of the [[Oracle#Greece|Greek oracular gods]]; she is nevertheless inspired to acknowledge out loud that the two missionaries of the "most high god" (''theos hypsistos''; see also [[Hypsistarians]]) know the way to [[salvation]]. For several days, she repeatedly voices this praise of Christianity. Although it is unclear why a Christian would dispute the truth of the ''paidiskê'' 's message, and although Jesus himself had said "anyone who is not against you is for you" (see [[Unclean spirit#In Christianity|above]] and {{bibleverse||Luke|9:49–50}}), Paul eventually grows annoyed and commands the ''pneuma'' to leave her.<ref>Shelly Matthews, ''First Converts: Rich Pagan Women and the Rhetoric of Mission in Early Judaism and Christianity'' (Stanford University Press, 2001), pp. 89–92 [https://books.google.com/books?id=mVg7zeCMxqQC&pg=PA89&dq=%22This+narrative+has+several+verbal+connections+to+the+exorcism+stories%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online], with additional citations of scholarship on the cultic identification of the ''paidiskê''. It has also been argued that since ''Hypsistos'' was a cult title for gods other than the [[Abrahamic religions#The Supreme Deity|one god of Abrahamic religions]], Paul struck back at the girl as a rival; see Paul Tribilco, "Paul and Silas, Servants of the Most High God - Acts 16:16-18," ''Journal for the Study of the New Testament'' 36 (1989) 51-73. This point of view is discussed and rejected by Irina Levinskaya, "God-fearers and the Cult of the Most High God," in ''The Book of Acts in Its Diaspora Setting'' (Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1996), pp. 98–100 [https://books.google.com/books?id=g3fb8guUfwEC&pg=PA98&dq=%22Trebilco+has+proposed+a+new+interpretation%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0 online]: "The demon was exorcised by Paul, not because of the content of his proclamation, but because the Christian mission did not need allies such as these" (p. 100). Discussion with emphasis on the slave-girl's perspective in Hans-Josef Klauck, ''Magic and Paganism in Early Christianity: The World of the Acts of the Apostles'' (T&T Clark, 2000), pp. 63–73.</ref>
This encounter differs from other exorcisms in the New Testament. Unlike Jesus, who usually heals at first contact, Paul drives away the spirit only after several days. The girl is depicted as neither physically tormented nor insane. A spell from the [[Greek Magical Papyri]] shows that the possessing ''pneuma'' could be welcomed as a giver of vision:
{{cquote|Greeting, spirit ''(pneuma)'' who enters into me, seizes me and then departs from me graciously in accordance with the will of the god … .<ref>[[Greek Magical Papyri]] IV.1121–24, ζόμενόν μου κατὰ θεοῦ βούληϲιν ἐν χρη ϲτότητι πνεῦμα, ''Papyri Graecae Magicae: Die griechischen Zauberpapyri'', edited by Karl Preisendanz (Teubner, 1973), vol. 1, p. 110. English translation by W.C. Grese in ''The Greek Magical Papyri in Translation'', edited by Hans Dieter Betz (University of Chicago Press, 1986), p. 60 [https://books.google.com/books?id=K0hCj5u3HNQC&pg=PA60&dq=%22Hail,+spirit+who+enters+into+me,+convulses+me%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3#v=onepage&q=%22Hail%2C%20spirit%20who%20enters%20into%20me%2C%20convulses%20me%22&f=false online.]</ref>}} Paul saw the competing gods of the Greeks as demons.<ref>''DDD'', p. 240; see {{bibleverse|1|Corinthians|10:20–21}} and {{bibleverse|1|Corinthians|12:1–11}}.</ref> There is no crowd to witness Paul's miracle and proclaim the deed, but later the masters of the ''paidiskê'' haul Paul and Silas into court for depriving them of a profitable business.<ref>Matthews, ''First Converts,'' pp. 89–90.</ref>
The message itself is composed of two patterns characteristic of [[Hellenistic civilization|Hellenistic]] oracle: a recognition ("These men are … "), and a commendation of their trustworthiness.<ref>Aune, ''Prophecy in Early Christianity'', pp. 268–269 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Rwn7ofAwNQ4C&pg=PA268&dq=pneuma+%22unclean+spirit%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=1929&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> The only divinely inspired speech by a woman recorded in the Acts is that of the ''paidiskê'', but she is characterized as mantic rather than prophetic.<ref>Matthews, ''First Converts,'' p. 89.</ref> Although both are forms of divination, [[Plato]] had distinguished the two: the ''mantis'' became the mouthpiece of the god through possession, but the "prophecy of interpretation" required specialized knowledge of how to read signs and omens and was considered a rational process. The '"prophet" (προφήτης), usually male, could interpret the divinely inspired speech of a mantic.<ref>[[Plato]], ''Timaeus'' 71e–72b and ''Phaedrus'' 244a–d, discussed by Gerald Hovenden, ''Speaking in Tongues: The New Testament Evidence in Context'' (Continuum International, 2002), pp. 22–23 [https://books.google.com/books?id=10PrS-7X2SMC&pg=PA21&dq=%22Plato+and+the+Two+Types+of+Prophecy%22+intitle:Speaking+intitle:in+intitle:tongues&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3 online.] "Mantic wisdom takes in a variety of means of finding the divine will, whereas prophecy is a form of 'spirit divination,' whether it comes spontaneously or is sought by inquiry," notes Lester L. Grabbe, introduction and overview, ''Knowing the End from the Beginning: The Prophetic, the Apocalyptic and Their Relationships'' (Continuum International, 2003), p. 24 [https://books.google.com/books?id=KuauhZijcb4C&pg=PA24&dq=%22mantic+wisdom+takes+in+a+variety+of+means%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0 online.]</ref>
[[File:Origen.jpg|thumb|left|100px|'''Origen''']] [[Plutarch]] gives ''Pythones'' as a [[synonym]] for ''engastrimythoi'' ("belly-talkers" or "[[ventriloquist]]s"), a suspect type of mantic who employed trickery in projecting a voice, sometimes through a device such as a mechanical snake. The snake was probably the chosen [[mediumship|medium]] because of its association in myth with Delphi, where Apollo killed the serpent (the [[Python (mythology)|Python]]) to establish his own oracle there. Plutarch and other ancient authors scoff at the notion that the god himself enters the body of a paid mantic for use as a mouthpiece. The early [[Church fathers]], however, attributed the behavior of ''engastrimythoi'' to demonic possession.<ref>Aune, ''Prophecy in Early Christianity'', pp. 40–42.</ref> Like Chrysostom, the early Christian theologian [[Origen]] finds the Pythia's receptive vagina disturbing<ref>"The prophetic spirit of Apollo, pure from any body of earth, secretly enters through the private parts the person who is called the priestess"; [[Origen]], ''[[Contra Celsum]]'' 3.25 and 7.3–7.</ref> and uses the gender of Apollo's oracle as a way to disparage the Delphic religion, saying that if Apollo were a true god, he would have chosen a male prophet:<ref>Matthews, ''First Converts'', p. 91.</ref>
{{cquote|If the Delphian Apollo were a god, as the Greeks suppose, would he not rather have chosen as his prophet some wise man? or if such an one was not to be found, then one who was endeavouring to become wise? How came he not to prefer a man to a woman for the utterance of his prophesies? And if he preferred the latter sex, as though he could only find pleasure in the breast of a woman, why did he not choose among women a virgin to interpret his will?<ref>Origen, ''Contra Celsum'' 7.5.</ref>}}
The sexual purity of a male prophet is not at issue, but sexual activity renders a woman unfit. The implication of sexual union between the god and a mortal woman is again viewed as a dangerous deception.
===''Pneumata plana''=== [[Image:Daemon.jpg|right|125px|thumb|Demonic ''porneia'' in a 13th-century [[allegory|allegorization]] of [[lust]]]] In [[First Epistle to Timothy|one of his epistles]] to [[Saint Timothy|Timothy]],<ref>{{bibleverse|1|Timothy|4:1}}.</ref> Paul defines [[apostasy|apostate]]s as those who are drawn to "deceiving" or "seductive" spirits (''pneumasin planois'') and demonic teachings (''didaskaliais daimoniôn''). {{bibleverse|1|John|4:6}} refers to: ''to pneuma tês planês'', "the spirit of error."
These ''pneumata plana'' are also found frequently in the [[apocryphal]] ''[[Testaments of the Twelve Patriarchs]]'', where they threaten to lead astray the [[Israelite]]s into varieties of immorality. The "seven spirits of deceit"<ref>''[[Testaments of the Twelve Patriarchs#Reuben|Testament of Reuben]]'' 2.1 and 3.2–7.</ref> are ''porneia'' (sexual sins),<ref>For the term ''porneia'', see definitions under [[Wife-for-life|Expounding of the Law]] and [[Religion and sexuality#Christianity|Religion and sexuality]].</ref> [[gluttony]], [[anger]], [[hypocrisy]], [[pride|arrogance]], [[lie|lying]], and [[injustice]]; "besides all these, the [[Morpheus (mythology)|spirit of sleep]], the eighth spirit, is conjoined with [[error]] and [[Fantasy (psychology)|fantasy]]."<ref>Jerome D. Quinn and William C. Wacker, ''The First and Second Letters to Timothy: A New Translation with Notes and Commentary'' (William B. Eerdmans Publishing, 2000), pp. 353–355 [https://books.google.com/books?id=1QIseKlznwkC&pg=PA353&dq=%22pneumata+plana%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; [https://books.google.com/books?id=7R0IGTSvIVIC&pg=PA195&dq=%22pneumata+plana%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA195,M1 online.] English translation available from [http://www.newadvent.org/fathers/0801.htm New Advent.] Compare [[Seven deadly sins]].</ref>
===''Pneuma astheneias''=== The phrase ''pneuma astheneias'', "spirit of infirmity" or "spirit of weakness," is unique in the New Testament to the [[Gospel of Luke]], as is the story in which it appears:
{{cquote|<sup>10</sup>And he was teaching in one of the synagogues on the sabbath day. <sup>11</sup>And behold, a woman that had a spirit of infirmity eighteen years; and she was bowed together, and could in no wise lift herself up. <sup>12</sup>And when Jesus saw her, he called her, and said to her, Woman, thou art loosed from thine infirmity. <sup>13</sup>And he laid his hands upon her: and immediately she was made straight, and glorified God.<ref>{{bibleverse||Luke|13:10–13}}, [[American Standard Version]].</ref>}}
[[Luke the Evangelist|Luke]] is the [[gospel]] writer who was a [[physician]], and while his profession may have motivated his interest, nothing suggests a [[medical diagnosis]]. ''Asthenia'' throughout the New Testament means "weakness" or "powerlessness" of any kind, including sickness. Some have seen the affliction as [[ankylosing spondylitis]], but an alternative interpretation is that hard labor over the years had bent the woman's back. The incident has been examined at length from the perspective of [[feminist theology]] by [[Francis Taylor Gench]], who views it as both healing and liberating; Jesus goes on to say that the woman has been freed from a kind of bondage to [[Satan]]. The breaking of bonds or chains is often associated with freedom from an unclean spirit; in the case of the [[Unclean spirit#Animals and liminality|Gerasene demon (above)]], the demoniac had the physical power to break chains as a result of possession.<ref>[[Francis Taylor Gench]], "A Bent Woman, Daughter of Abraham (Luke 13:10–17)," in ''Back to the Well: Women's Encounters with Jesus in the Gospels'' (Westminster John Knox Press, 2004), pp. 84–108, limited preview [https://books.google.com/books?id=mBWhxl5JBpMC&pg=PA84&dq=%22only+luke+among+the+evangelists%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref>
===''Pneuma alalon''=== The ''pneuma alalon'' is a speechless spirit who renders the possessed mute (Greek ''alalon,'' "without speech"). It thus differs from most possessing demons, who are given to taunts and mockery (''diabolos'', the origin of both "diabolic" and "[[Devil]]," means "slanderer" in Greek). {{bibleverse||Mark|9:14–29}} relates that a boy is brought to Jesus for healing because he cannot speak; verse 25 adds that he cannot hear. This demonic possession manifests itself through symptoms that resemble [[epilepsy]], as is suggested also by {{bibleverse||Matthew|17:15}}, who uses a form of the colloquial verb ''seleniazetai'' ("moonstruck") for the condition.<ref>The event is also narrated by Luke 9:37–49.</ref> Although traditionally [[Epilepsy#History|epilepsy was regarded as "the sacred disease,"]] Jews and Christians attributed the affliction to a demon. The [[Babylonian Talmud]] specifies that a child's epilepsy was caused by "the [[Šulak (demon)|demon of the privy]]," which attached to the father when he had sex too soon after [[excretion|relieving himself]]; that is, he was impure:
{{cquote|After coming back from the [[toilet|lavatory]] ''(bet ha-kissê)'', one should wait [some time] before sexual intercourse, as the [[Šulak (demon)|demon of the lavatory]] accompanies him. If he does not wait, the offspring will be epileptic.<ref>[[Babylonian Talmud]], Tractate ''[[Nashim#Gittin|Gittin]]'' 70a: From Marten Stol, ''Epilepsy in Babylonia'' (Brill, 1993), p. 76 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Tu-MYstDdvoC&pg=PA76&dq=Gittin+70a+epilepsy&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] See also Joel Marcus, ''Mark 8–16: A New Translation with Introduction and Commentary'', Yale [[Anchor Bible]] series (Yale University Press, 2009), p. 652 [https://books.google.com/books?id=WPlh-D32yDMC&pg=PA652&dq=%22pneuma+alalon%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; John R. Donahue and Daniel J. Harrington, ''The Gospel of Mark'' (Liturgical Press, 2002), p. 227 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xZAIsUZOwSQC&pg=PA277&dq=%22pneuma+alalon%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref>}}
====Unforgivable sin==== [[File:Mihaly Munkacsy Head of a Pharisee.jpg|thumb|125px|''Head of a Pharisee'' ([[Mihály Munkácsy]], 1881)]] {{Main|Unforgivable sin}} Before Jesus, exorcism had been conducted by a trained practitioner who offered a diagnosis and administered a ritual usually employing spoken formularies, amulets or other objects, or compounds of substances resembling pharmacological recipes of the time. Jesus's approach seemed radical because it depended on spiritual authority alone.<ref>''DDD'', p. 237.</ref> Jesus casts out the ''pneuma alalon'' in front of a crowd who exclaim "Nothing like this has ever happened in [[History of ancient Israel and Judah|Israel]]!" The [[Pharisees]], also witnesses, counter that "the [[Hierarchy of demons|leader of the demons]] gives him power to force out demons."<ref>Matthew 9:32–34 ([[Contemporary English Version]]).</ref> This accusation leads to the "[[Beelzebub]] controversy." {{bibleverse||Mark|3:29–30}} warns that attributing the power of the [[Holy Spirit]] to possession by an "unclean spirit" is a [[Eternal sin|sin that cannot be forgiven]]. The [[theology|theological]] concept is difficult and subject to varying interpretations.<ref>Mark S. Krause, "Unforgivable Sin," ''Eerdmans Dictionary of the Bible'', pp. 1345–1346 [https://books.google.com/books?id=P9sYIRXZZ2MC&pg=PA1345&dq=%22A+phenomenon+also+called+the+%22unpardonable+sin.%22%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref>
In {{bibleverse||Mark|3:20–22}}, Jesus returns home from performing miracles, but a crowd gathers: "There were so many people that Jesus and his followers could not eat. When his family heard this, they went to get him because they thought he was out of his mind. But the teachers of [[Halakha|the law]] from [[History of Jerusalem|Jerusalem]] were saying, '[[Beelzebul]] is living inside him! He uses his power from the ruler of demons to force demons out of people'."<ref>[[New Century Version]] translation.</ref> In his response to this accusation, Jesus says that speaking out against the Holy Spirit is an unforgivable sin: "Jesus said this because the people were saying that he had an evil spirit in him."<ref>Mark 3:28–30 (Contemporary English Version).</ref> {{bibleverse||Luke|12:10}} clarifies that "if you speak against the [[Son of Man]], you can be forgiven, but if you speak against the Holy Spirit, you cannot be forgiven."
===Early Christian exorcism=== In the period of [[History of Christianity#Post-Apostolic Church|post-Apostolic Christianity]], [[baptism]] and the [[Eucharist]] required the prior riddance of both unclean spirits and illness.<ref>William Brashear and Roy Kotansky, "A New Magical Prayer Formulary," in ''Magic and Ritual in the Ancient World'', edited by Paul Mirecki and Marvin Meyer (Brill, 2002), p. 13 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xMDHgzjSU_MC&pg=PA13&dq=%22the+ridding+of+demons+and+illness%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> Because the possessing demon was conceptualized as a ''pneuma'' or ''spiritus'', each of which derives from a root meaning "breath," one term for its expulsion was [[Insufflation#Insufflation vs. exsufflation|exsufflation]], or a "blowing out."<ref>For medieval liturgical examples — the Rheinau Ritual (12th century), Constance Ritual (1482), and the Magdeburg Agenda (1492) — see Bryan D. Spinks, ''Early and Medieval Rituals and Theologies of Baptism: From the New Testament to the Council of Trent'' (Ashgate Publishing, 2006), p. 136 [https://books.google.com/books?id=JVV1IEHV6jkC&pg=PA136&dq=%22unclean+spirit%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#v=onepage&q=%22unclean%20spirit%22&f=false online] and 138.</ref>
Exorcistic texts with Christian content have been found in [[papyrology|papyri]] along with syncretic magic spells; in one Greek example of a fragmentary [[Recto and verso|leaf]] from a [[codex]], an exorcism that alludes to the [[Nativity of Jesus|birth of Jesus]] and his miracles appears along with a spell for silencing opponents, an invocation of the [[Serpent (symbolism)|Serpent]], a spell against a thief, a spell to achieve an [[erection]], a "sacred [[stele]],"<ref>In both the [[Near East]] and the [[Greco-Roman world]], a [[stele]] inscribed with images and text might be a focal point of [[Cult (religious practice)|cult practice]]. Magic papyri on occasion contain text to be inscribed on a stele; see for instance [[Georg Luck]], ''Arcana Mundi: Magic and the Occult in the Greek and Roman Worlds. A Collection of Ancient Texts'' (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1985; 2nd edition 2006), p. 139 [https://books.google.com/books?id=g7EKsAdHdL4C&pg=PA139&dq=%22sacred+stele%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; full text in translation with Hebraic elements in Hans Dieter Betz, ''The Greek Magical Papyri in Translation, Including the Demotic Spells'' (University of Chicago Press, 1996), vol. 1, p. 174 [https://books.google.com/books?id=K0hCj5u3HNQC&pg=PA174&dq=%22sacred+stele%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] Two types of stele are contained in the papyri: a drawing with or without writing, and an inscribed charm.</ref> and a series of magical letters (χαρακτῆρες). The exorcism is distinguished from other early Christian magic charms that quote Bible verses and [[Psalms]] by its use of [[liturgy|liturgical]] [[antiphony|antiphonies]] and references to Christian [[creed]].<ref>William Brashear and Roy Kotansky, "A New Magical Formulary," in ''Magic and Ritual in the Ancient World'', edited by Paul Mirecki and [[Marvin Meyer]] (Brill, 2002), pp. 3–24, especially pp. 10–11 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xMDHgzjSU_MC&pg=PA10&dq=%22Christian+Liturgical+Exorcism%22+intitle:Magic+intitle:and+intitle:ritual+intitle:in+intitle:the+intitle:ancient+intitle:world&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online], English translation [https://books.google.com/books?id=xMDHgzjSU_MC&pg=PA9&dq=%22For+those+troubled+by+%5Bevil%5D+dem%5Bons%5D%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES p. 9.]</ref>
The unclean spirit associated with a particular possession, or feared possession, might be identified as an individual and named. [[Gello|Gyllou]], a type of reproductive demon that appears on [[Aramaic]] [[amulet]]s in late antiquity, is described in a Greek text as "abominable and unclean" (μιαρὰ καὶ ἀκάθαρτος, ''miara kai akathartos''),<ref>Joseph Naveh and Shaul Shaked, ''Amulets and [[Incantation bowls|Magic Bowls]]: Aramaic Incantations of Late Antiquity'' (Jerusalem: Magnes Press, 1985), pp. 112–113; see also Karen Hartnup, ''On the Beliefs of the Greeks: Leo Allatios and Popular Orthodoxy'' (Brill, 2004), p. 88 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xnqI8uSeekwC&pg=PA87&dq=unclean+inauthor:Hartnup&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA88,M1 online] and p. 144 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xnqI8uSeekwC&pg=PA87&dq=unclean+inauthor:Hartnup&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA144,M1 online.]</ref> and is the object of a prayer to [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|the Virgin Mary]] asking for protection.<ref>Hartnup, ''On the Beliefs of the Greeks'', p. 97 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xnqI8uSeekwC&pg=PA97&dq=%22Therefore+I+pray,+my+Lady%22+inauthor:Hartnup&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online], citing Allatios, ''De opinionibus'' VII, p. 132.</ref>
===''Spiritus immundus''=== [[File:Lincoln imp.jpg|thumb|100px|[[Lincoln Imp|Imp]] of the [[Lincoln Cathedral]]]] [[File:Holy water dispenser.jpg|thumb|100px|Cask of [[holy water]] at [[Limburg Cathedral]], with a sign reading "Holy water to take away"]] In his ''Decretum'', [[Burchard of Worms]] asserts that "we know that unclean spirits ''(spiritus immundi)'' who fell from the heavens wander about between the sky and earth," drawing on the view expressed in the ''[[Commentary on Job|Moralia in Job]]'' of [[Pope Gregory I|Gregory I]]. In his [[penitential]], Burchard says that some people wait until cock's crow — that is, dawn — to go outdoors because they feared ''spiritus immundi''. The fear is not treated as groundless; rather, Burchard recommends [[Christ]] and the [[sign of the cross]] as protection, rather than reliance on the cock's crow. The exact nature of these ''immundi'' is unclear: they may have been demons, woodland beings such as [[imp]]s, or ghosts of the unhallowed dead.<ref>Bernadette Filotas, ''Pagan Survivals, Superstitions, and Popular Cultures in Early Medieval Pastoral Literature'' (Pontifical Institute of Mediaeval Studies, 2005), p. 82 [https://books.google.com/books?id=qh1lrIM5nd4C&pg=PA82&dq=%22we+know+that+unclean+spirits%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%22we%20know%20that%20unclean%20spirits%22&f=false online.]</ref>
====Latin liturgy and exorcism==== ''Spiritus immundus'' is the term corresponding to ''pneuma akatharton'' to address the demon in Latin [[exorcism]]s;<ref>Frederick Edward Warren, ''The Liturgy and Ritual of the [[Celtic Christianity|Celtic Church]]'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1881), pp. 210 and 214 [https://books.google.com/books?id=h80YAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA214&dq=%22spiritus+immundus%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; Alexander Murray, '' Suicide in the Middle Ages: The Curse on Self-murder'' (Oxford University Press, 2000), p. 476, note 73 [https://books.google.com/books?id=PMa7SYvpcM8C&pg=RA2-PA476&dq=%22spiritus+immundus%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=1&as_miny_is=2009&as_maxm_is=12&as_maxy_is=2009&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PRA2-PA476,M1 online.]</ref> see ''[[Of Exorcisms and Certain Supplications]]'' for text from a modern [[solemnity|solemn]] exorcism adjuring the "unclean spirit" to depart a possessed person. In [[Celtic Rite]], the unclean spirit is evoked and exorcized ''per deum patrem omnipotentem'', "by God, All-powerful Father"; the same phrase is used in both [[Gallican rite|Gallican]] (''exorcidio te, spiritus immunde'') and [[Ambrosian rite|Milanese]] exorcism. The Milanese rite prescribes [[exsufflation]]: ''Exsufflat in faciem ejus in similitudinem crucis dum dicit'' ("Breathe out onto [the subject's] face in the likeness of the cross while speaking").<ref>[[Baptism#Baptism and salvation in Roman Catholic teaching|Ordo Baptismi]], [[Celtic Rite|Sacramentarium Gallicanum]], edition of [[Jean Mabillon]] p. 324; also in an [[Ambrosian Rite|Ambrosian Ritual]] (Ordo xxi) quoted by [[Edmond Martène]], ''De Antiquis Ecclesiae Ritibus'' (1788), vol. 1, p. 80. Frederick Edward Warren, ''The Liturgy and Ritual of the Celtic Church'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1881), p. 220 [https://books.google.com/books?id=k1ArAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA220&dq=%22spiritus+immunde%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref>
Such exorcisms are performed rarely by the 21st-century [[Latin liturgical rites|Western church]]; the more common exorcism involves the ritual preparation of [[holy water]] (''aquae''). The 9th-century [[Stowe Missal]] preserves an early Celtic formula as ''procul ergo hinc, iubente te, domine, omnis spiritus immundus abscedat'' ("Therefore at your bidding, Lord, let every unclean spirit depart far from here").<ref>Frederick Edward Warren, ''The Liturgy and Ritual of the Celtic Church'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1881), p. 214.</ref> In a Latin version of ''The [[Holy Water|Blessing of the Waters]] on the Eve of [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]]'' performed in Rome and recorded at the turn of the 19th–20th centuries, the unclean spirit is commanded ''per Deum vivum'' ("by the Living God").<ref>John, [[Marquess of Bute]], with E.A. Wallis Budge, ''The [[Holy Water|Blessing of the Waters]] on the Eve of [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]]'' (London, 1901), p. 35 [https://books.google.com/books?id=FgEPAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA35&dq=%22Exorcizo+te+spiritus+immunde%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA35,M1 online.]</ref> The modern Latin rite to exorcize holy water banishes any "pestilent spirit" (''spiritus pestilens'') or "corrupting atmosphere" (''corrumpens aura''); see [[Holy water#Rituals and uses of holy water|Rituals and uses of holy water]].
